												Oddworld: Abe's Exoddus is a landmark game, and worthy sequel to the original Abe's Oddysee.Even in its now-limited screen resolution, the strong visual design of Abe's Exoddus shines through. Don't expect to run this game at your native resolution (unless you never upgraded beyond 800x600 - in which case, you're in luck!), but do expect the following: some fantastic and challenging platforming gameplay; a vast number of gorgeous levels interwoven with an interesting, dark and downright odd narrative; some brilliant music which changes dynamically depending on the events taking place; and finally, some fiendish puzzles which make use of Abe's talent for posession and the use of GameSpeak - a system by which you can instruct other characters to whatever ends you desire, be it salvation or something more nefarious.If you've played it before, there's no better time to return to the original Oddworld titles before enjoying the delights of the HD Remake, New N' Tasty, which recreates the events of the original game in a modern game engine and is "coming soon". If you're new to the series, don't be put off by the age or initial difficulty curve. Exoddus has a quick save system, so you'll never lose progress as long as you're diligent. A must-play!

												One of the best platformers ever made, Abe's Exooddus is a direct sequel of Abe's Oddysee and features even more levels than it's predecessor, while also bringing the most requested features of the last game, namely the ability to quicksave, restart levels where you messed up and all-talk.The game features plenty of mechanics and contains sections of stealth, logic, agility and sometimes observance.To name one of the mechanics that makes this particular game stand out, you have the ability to posses enemies and use them in your advantage to either destroy their own kind or free your path. Every single type of enemy has different types of abilities and limitations and it's up to you to figure them out. Some levels even prevent you from using your powers so you will have to use your brain to find a way around.The game also throws a challenge at you. Fellow enslaved people of your race are scattered around levels and it's up to you to talk to and lead them to portals that bring them to their freedom. You can either succeed or get them killed in the process, or even ignore them altogether and continue in your journey. You can command them using the talk system, unless they're mad or depressed, where you'll have to console them first, or smack the crap out of those affected by laughing gas.I personally think that's a very unique mechanic. Sometimes you'll have to clear a whole level then come back to the very beginning and escort your pals. Blind ones are also present and telling them to stop in their path is mandatory for their survival.You'll be rewarded for saving many of your kind but punished for refusing to or saving too few.The atmosphere of this game, like the first, is amazing. The story elements, the setting, the soundtrack and the characters make it up for one of the greatest cinematic experiences I've ever experienced. The graphics and the cutscenes are pre-rendered 3D sequences and they look just great for a game that came two decades ago. I should probably also mention that this game, unlike other titles on Steam that originally came during the 90's, fully works on both modern and old systems.I don't really have negative feedback about this game. It's one of the things that made up my childhood and replaying it was a lot of joy. I guess that there were a few annoying levels that felt a bit repetitive(the ones that feature fleeches for instance), but other than that, everything is godlike. I highly recommend this game to anyone.Fart in a platformer today!

												Nominated for the “test of time” award. This was my absolute favourite game when I was a kid and I still love it to this day.It may be partly because I only owned about 3 games at the time but I must've sunk more hours into this game than any other.The atmosphere and world are great, a dark story with just the right amount of humour. Abe is the last hope to free his enslaved people, who are forced to work in dangerous conditions by greedy slave traders who care only about profit, but if you get bored of all that you can press a button to make Abe fart, which causes all Mudokons next to him to take step back, and those further away to giggle. Gameplaywise Abe’s Exoddus is a puzzle-platformer with the emphasis on the platforming over the puzzling. Most of the puzzles are easy to figure out, but actually completing them is another thing. It manages to fall into that elusive sweet spot of “challenging but fair”. You will die a lot but the game rarely resorts to fake-difficult instant-death traps. I remember playing some of these levels for the first time, I almost smashed my keyboard in frustration and yet every time I screwed up I knew it was my own fault. Each failure leaves you even more determined to finally beat this damn level.This game seems to be less popular than its predecessor, Abe’s Oddysee, (although that may just be my group of friends) but I definitely prefer this one. Partly because I actually played this sequel before the original but also in large part because of the addition of quicksave. There is nothing more frustrating than completing a particularly difficult section and then dying 3 steps from a checkpoint and the quicksave handily eliminates that frustration.The graphics are somewhat dated but it still looks pretty good for its age, besides it’s only $3 - or even less if you wait for a sale - what more could you want? Highly recommended, especially for any fans of old-school platformers.

												Not only is this a fantastic game, an instant 10/10, the fact that it costs only £2 makes it one of the best value-for-money games I've ever seen on Steam, at least not including sales. It took me 20 hours to complete this game, so that's £1 per 10 hours.The game itself is a classic, growing on what made Abe's Oddysee so great, and while I think Exoddus lacks the atmosphere that made the original so enjoyable, the gameplay itself is much more varied (though I still prefer Oddysee). The cutscenes are better, the music is more complex (if not a tad generic), there are more places and environments to see, and there are more types of puzzles based on the emotion system with the Mudokons. They can be angry, depressed, wired (in other words happy), sick, and blind. This means a lot more is explored as to how the Mudokons interact with you, and especially trying to handle the wired Mudokons running about with enemies, bombs and motion sensors around can get very tense.You can also autosave, another improvement from Oddysee that makes the game much less frustrating.I have 2 complaints, however; the first being there are a few ridiculous chase sections that force you to duck and react quickly with a movement system not internded for fast-paced action, rather slow-moving stealth. The game also overstays it's welcome a bit, getting dragged out for a few more hours than it really needed to last.Speaking of stealth, once again every single enemy can make your palms sweat all over your controller, especially if you have some blind Mudokons you have to escort.One more thing; the graphics, for 1998, are amazing. I found myself stopping and gazing at some of the fantastically detailed backdrops of places like Necrum and the Soulstorm Brewery. It's dark and beautifully rendered.Anyway, get the game now. It's bloody great.

												I can honestly say that this is my absolute favourite game ever, and I am happy that it's on Steam since my PS1 broke down. I really believe that this game gets heavily overlooked when it comes to naming the top games of its generation. Oddworld: Abe's Oddysee gets mentioned quite a bit, but this one... not so much. Which is a damn shame, and I'll explain why in a minute.The only downside to this was getting it playable was a little difficult. Resolution issues are the first big problem, though that was easy to fix with a quick download of a program. Now the only minor annoyance is that because its natural resolution was 800x600, stretching that to my 1920x1080 caused it to because a little more pixelated and blurry. You can still see everything perfectly fine, its mostly just distant objects or background things during the cutscenes that may be difficult to make out.Controller compatibility isn't labelled, but it is there, to a degree. I was prepared to use my Xbox 360 controller, but the default mapped controls for it were a mess (chanting was the 'Back' button of all buttons). Honestly, it's easier and probably better to just stick with the keyboard. Any remapping you deem necessary is much less stressful.As for the gameplay... If you've played Abe's Oddysee, then everything you saw there was improved on here, and for the better. Extra voice commands, emotions of the Mudokons to deal with, often in hilarious ways (particularly with the laughing gas). Possession of enemies ranges further than sligs (who also now have a flying variation). The wider range of enemies, the much more intimidating puzzles, the fact that the major bad guys are actually a within bits and pieces of the game and become a mechanic themselves rather than just be seen and death with via cutscenes... and at its worst, some areas just require careful timing. The game is incredibly simple for the things you can do.The backgrounds for the environments are spectacular, the music... isn't the stuff of legends, but I have found myself humming or whistling a couple of the tunes here and there. But otherwise the only other major factor is the story, and it's just as weird and twisted as the original. It kicks off right where Oddysee ended (poor Abe doesn't even get time to rest).And here's a fun fact. Back in the late 90's when this game originally came out, most of this games cutscenes were turned into a short film. A short film that was nominated for an Oscar. A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Academy Award! Technically speaking, the first and (I could be wrong with this one) only game to have achieved that.Besides the questionable performance issues in getting the game going, majority of which easily fixed, I recommend this game and recommend it hard. While I'm at it, I also recommend Abe's Oddysee (or its HD remake 'New n' Tasty'). While it may be a childhood love of mine, it's been 17 years and I can still call it my favourite.I'm at a point where I can play at least 30% of it with sound alone, and I'm still not sick of this game. It's just that kind of game that I can pick up and play any day of the year.TL;DR - If you liked Oddysee, you'll like Exoddus better. If you haven't played it, PLAY IT!

												Along the same premise as the first game, the Mudokons you're trying to rescue in Exoddus are much more complex than the original assembly. Besides the occasional drunk, blind, or just generally resistant creature, they all emote like mood rings, showing red skin when angry and an off-color greenish yellow and pale tone when sick. You have to find healing rings from Shaman Mudokons and apologize and shoulder-pat to make angry ones happy again so they'll follow you to safety. And blind Mudokons have a tendency to walk into drills and off of ledges if you don't guide them properly with verbal cues. On a positive note, you can use their blindness to your benefit. For example, if a blind Mudokon is on the level below you, notably the one with the lever you need to pull but can't get to, you can stand on the side of the screen you want the blind guy to walk toward, prompt him to follow you, and then tell him to "work" in order to turn the crank or pull the lever that allows you access to another level. Another excellent function is being able to guide more than one Mudokon at a time. In the first game, you had to rescue one Mudokon, then come back and get the other one. In Exoddus, you have an "All o' ya" command that captures the attention of anyone present. At points, you'll have a gaggle trailing behind you - sneaking, running, or jumping into the bird teleporters.But perhaps even better than the hammed-up gamespeak is the fact that the developers fixed what could easily be called the number one problem with the first game: the inability to save the game wherever you wanted. Not only was Abe's Oddysee a tough game, you spent a lot of time redoing what you'd done because of the need to learn the hard way. Many of the puzzles in the original required some testing before you made it through, and when you have to go all the way back to the beginning of the path each time you fail, it's hard to stay inspired to push forward. In Exoddus, you have an incredibly welcomed quick-save option that allows you to quickly save your progress, anywhere in the game as many times as you want. And when you're ready to quit playing, you simply save to the memory card instead of a quick save, and you're set. This introduces an interesting dilemma, as the quick save certainly makes Exoddus seem easier, in a sense, but the game itself is actually even more difficult than the first one - it's just that now you finally have hope. And just when you think hope's lost, something wonderful like an invisibility power-up appears when you free Mudokon spirits.Graphically, Abe's Exoddus is the same 2D visual wonder, much like the original or, moreover, Interplay's Heart of Darkness. Yet the graphics seem much more brilliant, as there are more environments with greater diversity in design. And the cutscenes are not only gorgeous, they're entertaining and (can I say it?) funny. No, really. Besides that, the game is quite large, and the environments are expansive. You'll have to rescue the spirits of Mudokons past; battle the typical, yet enhanced cast of Sligs, Scrabs, and the excruciatingly annoying Fleeches (long live the quick save), among others; as well as roll through the mines in mine carts and such. And sound-wise, you really can't get much better without being downright distracting. The voices of all the characters are incredible, and the effects, from getting blown up by a mine to the echoey sound of falling to your death, really can't be beat.Abe's Exoddus also has a two-player mode. While the Exoddus mainstay is clearly the single-player game, the two-player co-op mode does have charm, as you and another player take turns working your way through. When you die, your partner picks up where you left off and so forth. A bit of advice? Pick a crummy partner, and you might have some fun with this. Otherwise, the waiting game just doesn't parallel the egocentric fun of keeping this title to yourself. In all, Abe's Exoddus is a great example of how a game can stay true to its conceptual pursuit while still improving upon the original, all while keeping its soul intact. If you loved the first one, you'll like this game more. If you didn't play the first one, you can start here. If you hated the first one, it's likely because of the lack of save points, so you should definitely consider giving this series another try.

Well, as best as I can.The PlotSo the plot is simple: Abe, the Mudokon who was formerly a floor-waxer for Rupture Farms before blowing it up, finds out of a despicable plan by the Glukkons through a group of dead spirits named The Three Weirdos. The burial ground of Necrum had been stolen from; bones were being mined by blinded Mudokons, as they were a required ingredient or the well-known beverage Soulstorm Brew. Upon finding this out, Abe sets out to Destroy the brewery and stop this new industrialist scheme. An okay plot, if I say so myself, despite being along similar lines as Oddysee. Controls: Movement, Gamespeak & PosessionThe gameplay is quite something. So let's get this out the way. Abe's normal controls, walking, running, rolling, jumping and all sorts are really smooth in a sense. They're responsive and flow well with the pace of the game, whether it be slow platforming or heart-pounding chases, and trust me, there are going to be lots of those. You're probably going to spend a lot of the time either walking, rolling or sneaking, as running is mainly essential for chases with Sligs, Scrabs and Paramites, which do crop up at just the right times. Jumping is precise and easy to do, y'just press the space button and you'll leap about two to three spaces forwards, which you learn and can pretty much master right off the bat. This nifty mechanic allows Abe to talk to his enslaved race and lead them to bird portals. A lot are simple: Hello, follow me, all of ya', wait, all that stuff. However, replacing the whistling from the last game, there are now options to slap, say sorry, tell people to stop. This was because in this game, the Mudokons have several emotions to work around, going from sad and angry, the blind Mudokons who will follow the sound of your voice but not you, or sick Mudokons who you have to heal with ring powers. There isn't much else to say here. Nifty.Posession is something that got a direct upgrade adding even MORE experimentation. Unlike last game where you could only posess Sligs, the gun-toting cyborg henchmen of the Magog Cartel, you can posess EVERYTHING here. Well, except for slogs. Scrabs? Check. Paramites? Check. The Glukkons who you can use to order around Sligs to do your bidding? Checkedy Checkedy Check. These all have their own curveballs, own Gamespeak, and own uses. Even though there aren't too many times you can posess Glukkons, and Phleg... Oh god, that part in Bonewerkz. Music and pictures This is where the game gets sublime. And by sublime, I mean some of the best atmosphere, music and art direction you're going to see. The score matches your enviroment perfectly. A few I can list off the top of my head are Necrum, the Mines, the Mudanchee & Mudumo Vaults, and then FeeCo Depot. Be it tribal instruments clashing and meshing to get the feel of a sacred area, or the mechanical and almost oppresive sounds of industrial areas like Necrum Mines or Soulstorm Brewery. All these tracks accompany the backgrounds perfectly. The amount of detail put into these images, the sheer blood and sweat clearly poored into this was worth the time, creating truly stunning pieces of art, such as all the areas involving the vaults or Necrum, which capture the sacred yet barren forest which has long been forgotten. This doesn't have to be the background either. Character animations, like the floor-wiping Mudokon slaves or even the mere act of climbing ledges or entering doors, are animated as smoothly and realistic as they possibly could be.  My Verdict: Well, what do I think of the game? It is timeless. A truly gorgeous blast from the past which will continue to amaze for quite some time, even if the newer games like Oddworld: Soulstorm flop! [Which I best will be nowhere near happening] If you're thinking about getting this game, go ahead. Only 1.99 pound, or at least for us English, and well worth the small amount of money you take out of your pockets to pay. a 10/10 from yours not so truly, Mr. Fanmemerofl. Stupid name, I know.

And when you're ready to quit playing, you simply save to the memory card instead of a quick save, and you're set. This introduces an interesting dilemma, as the quick save certainly makes Exoddus seem easier, in a sense, but the game itself is actually even more difficult than the first one - it's just that now you finally have hope. And just when you think hope's lost, something wonderful like an invisibility power-up appears when you free Mudokon spirits.Graphically, Abe's Exoddus is the same 2D visual wonder, much like the original or, moreover, Interplay's Heart of Darkness. Yet the graphics seem much more brilliant, as there are more environments with greater diversity in design. And the cutscenes are not only gorgeous, they're entertaining and (can I say it?) funny. No, really. Besides that, the game is quite large, and the environments are expansive. You'll have to rescue the spirits of Mudokons past; battle the typical, yet enhanced cast of Sligs, Scrabs, and the excruciatingly annoying Fleeches (long live the quick save), among others; as well as roll through the mines in mine carts and such. And sound-wise, you really can't get much better without being downright distracting. The voices of all the characters are incredible, and the effects, from getting blown up by a mine to the echoey sound of falling to your death, really can't be beat.Abe's Exoddus also has a two-player mode. While the Exoddus mainstay is clearly the single-player game, the two-player co-op mode does have charm, as you and another player take turns working your way through. When you die, your partner picks up where you left off and so forth. A bit of advice? Pick a crummy partner, and you might have some fun with this. Otherwise, the waiting game just doesn't parallel the egocentric fun of keeping this title to yourself. In all, Abe's Exoddus is a great example of how a game can stay true to its conceptual pursuit while still improving upon the original, all while keeping its soul intact. If you loved the first one, you'll like this game more. If you didn't play the first one, you can start here. If you hated the first one, it's likely because of the lack of save points, so you should definitely consider giving this series another try.

												While Abe's Oddysee certainly deserves a lot of credit, it is not without fault. The excellent level design, short-but-sweet story, and grand scope of it was hampered predominantly by its checkpoint system. Each portion of a stage would throw three or four challenges at you between each checkpoint, not counting any hidden mudokons. As a result, there were many cases when several parts of a particular stage were easy but fairly slow and time consuming, while later parts were significantly more difficult and led to multiple deaths. Having to replay the earlier, easier parts quickly became very tedious very fast. In some games, this sort of thing doesn't hurt the game, but here, where the gameplay is built around trial and error, and often demands a great deal of patience, it killed the pacing at several points towards the beginning and middle of the game.I'm mentioning this because Abe's Exoddus included a quicksave feature which circumvented this problem, and for that reason alone could be considered a better game. That's not the only feather in Abe's Exoddus' cap though. The inclusion of such a feature as quicksave can fundamentally change a game like this, and Oddworld Inhabitants clearly kept this in mind. The level design is more challenging than Abe's Oddysee, but more fair. Secrets, previously pretty cryptic and very easy to overlook without the help of a guide, are now found by some out-of-the-box thinking and creative use of the game's mechanics. The core gameplay and overall design have been tweaked to remove tedium. The mechanics have been greatly expanded upon in order to provide much more variety and complexity. The voice acted cutscenes lend the world much more character, and add a great deal of levity to a game that could very easily become quite depressing.No matter how you look at it, Abe's Exoddus is the better of the two side scrolling games (as of writing this, New 'n' Tasty is still PS4 exclusive, so I can't comment on it yet). It manages to correct the flaws of it's predecessor while also expanding upon everything that was good. It really is what every sequel should strive to be. More of the good, plenty that's new, none of the bad.
